summary.text:
Pattern class.
The core building block of Satori. Patterns represent time-varying values over cycles.
Add a value or pattern.
Compare values. If both are true, return 1, else 0.

content.text:
```ts
coin().and(coin()) // returns 1 when both coins() are true
```

summary.text: Return the current cycle as an integer.

content.text:
```ts
c() // current cycle
```

```ts
c(4) // current cycle modulo 4
```

summary.text: Fill a cache with x values and repeat them once per cycle.

content.text:
```ts
coin().cache(16) // caches 16 values from coin() and repeats once per cycle.
```

```ts
random().cache(8, every(4)) // caches 8 random values, and refreshes the cache every 4 cycles.
```

summary.text: Concat values, one per cycle.

content.text:
```ts
cat('A', 'B', 'C') // A for 1 cycle, B for 1 cycle, C for 1 cycle.
```

summary.text: Randomly choose from a set of values.

content.text:
```ts
choose('A', 'B', 'C') // randomly chooses A, B, or C each cycle.
```

summary.text: Clamp pattern values to a given range.

content.text:
```ts
random().mul(10).clamp(2, 4) // clamps random()*10 values to between 2 and 4
```

summary.text: Return an equal distribution of 1s and 0s.

content.text:
```ts
coin()
```

summary.text: Generate a cosine wave from min to max over one cycle

content.text:
```ts
cosine(0, 1) // a cosine wave from 0 to 1 over the course of 1 cycle
```

summary.text: Increment a counter each time a condition is met.

content.text:
```ts
coin().count() // increments the count each time coin() returns 1
```

```ts
count(coin()) // same as above
```

summary.text: Return the current cycles per second.
Cycles to milliseconds.

content.text:
```ts
(4).ctms() // convert a number as a method
```

```ts
ctms(1) // or as a function
```

```ts
'1 2 3 4'.ctms() // convert a mini pattern string
```

```ts
seq(1,2,3,4).ctms() // convert a Pattern
```

summary.text: Convert cycles to seconds.

content.text:
```ts
(4).cts() // convert a number as a method
```

```ts
cts(1) // or as a function
```

```ts
'1 2 3 4'.cts() // convert a mini pattern string
```

```ts
seq(1,2,3,4).cts() // convert a Pattern
```

summary.text: Randomly replace values with 0.

content.text:
```ts
sine().degrade(0.3) // randomly replaces 30% of sine wave values with 0
```

summary.text: Divide a value or pattern.
Equal to comparison. Returns 1 if value == threshold, else 0.

content.text:
```ts
seq(1,2,3).eq(saw(0,4,3)) // compares each value with saw values
```

summary.text: Return a 1 every n cycles, else 0. Only returns 1 when event falls exactly on the cycle division.

content.text:
```ts
every(0.25) // returns 1 every quarter cycle. Equivalent to seq(1,1,1,1).
```

```ts
every(2) // returns 1 every 2 cycles. Equivalent to seq(1).slow(2).
```

summary.text: Expand the current value into a list of n values. An optional function can be provided to transform each value.

content.text:
```ts
'C'.expand(3) // returns stack('C', 'C', 'C')
```

```ts
'C'.expand(3, (note, i) => note + i * 2) // returns stack('C', 'D', 'E')
```

```ts
s1.set({
   inst: 'synth', n: 'C4*2'.expand(16, (x,i) => x+i*2),
   strum: ctms(1/8),
   e: every(2) })
```

summary.text: Speed up a pattern.

content.text:
```ts
seq('A', 'B', 'C').fast(3) // A for 1/3 cycle, B for 1/3 cycle, C for 1/3 cycle.
```

summary.text: Use a custom function to transform pattern values.
Greater than comparison. Returns 1 if value > threshold, else 0.

content.text:
```ts
seq(1,2,3).gt(saw(0,4,3)) // compares each value with saw values
```

summary.text: Alias for ifelse.
If else control structure for patterns.

content.text:
```ts
ifelse(coin(), 'A', 'B') // returns 'A' when coin() is true, else 'B'
```

```ts
random().lt(0.3).ifelse('A', 'B') // returns 1 when random()<0.3, else 0
```

summary.text: Interpolate values.

content.text:
```ts
sine().interp(saw()) // interpolates between sine and saw waveforms over time
```

summary.text: Assuming a chord pattern, invert the chord by a given number of steps.

content.text:
```ts
'Cma#7'.invert(1) // returns 'E G B C'
```

```ts
'Cma#7'.invert(-1) // returns 'B C E G'
```

summary.text: Less than comparison. Returns 1 if value < threshold, else 0.

content.text:
```ts
seq(1,2,3).lt(saw(0,4,3)) // compares each value with saw values
```

summary.text: Parse a mini pattern string into a Pattern instance.

content.text:
```ts
mini('Cmaj7..?') // parses the mini pattern string into a Pattern
```

summary.text: Modulo by a value or pattern.
Map from one range to another.
Multiply a value or pattern.
Not equal to comparison. Returns 1 if value != threshold, else 0.

content.text:
```ts
seq(1,2,3).neq(saw(0,4,3)) // compares each value with saw values
```

summary.text: Noise waveform from min to max over one cycle.

content.text:
```ts
noise() // noise values between 0 and 1
```

```ts
noise(5, 10) // noise values between 5 and 10
```

```ts
noise().slow(3) // noise values between 0 and 1, slowed down over 3 cycles
```

summary.text: If a value is true, negate it (1 -> 0, 0 -> 1).

content.text:
```ts
coin().not() // returns 1 when coin() is 0, else 0
```

```ts
not(coin()) // same as above
```

summary.text: Return mostly 1s, occasionally 0s.

content.text:
```ts
often()
```

summary.text: Compare values. If one of them is true, return 1, else 0.

content.text:
```ts
coin().or(coin()) // returns 1 when either coin() is true
```

summary.text: Print the current Pattern value for debugging.

content.text:
```ts
seq('A', 'B', 'C').print() // prints the value of the pattern on each division of the cycle.
```

summary.text: Generate a pulse wave from min to max over one cycle.

content.text:
```ts
pulse(0, 1, 0.25) // a pulse wave from 0 to 1 with a duty cycle of 25% over the course of 1 cycle
```

summary.text: Alias for saw
Alias for saw
Return mostly 0s, occasionally 1s

content.text:
```ts
rarely()
```

summary.text: Generate a ramp from min to max, once per cycle.

content.text:
```ts
saw(0,4) // a ramp from 0 to 4 over the course of 1 cycle
```

```ts
saw(0,1,96).slow(2) // a ramp from 0 to 1 over the course of 2 cycles, with finer steps to mitigate the slow pattern
```

summary.text: Alias for mtr.
Sequence values into a single cycle.

content.text:
```ts
seq('A', 'B', 'C', 'D') // A for .25 cycle, B for .25 cycle ... D for .25 cycle
```

summary.text: Alias for cat.
Generate a sine wave from min to max over one cycle.

content.text:
```ts
sine(0, 1) // a sine wave from 0 to 1 over the course of 1 cycle
```

```ts
sine(-1, 1, 96).slow(2) // a sine wave from -1 to 1 over the course of 2 cycles, with finer steps to mitigate the slow pattern
```

summary.text: Slow down a pattern.

content.text:
```ts
seq('A', 'B', 'C').slow(2) // A for 2 cycles, B for 2 cycles, C for 2 cycles.
```

summary.text: Alias for coin
Alias for pulse with a duty cycle of 0.5.

content.text:
```ts
square(0, 4) // a square wave from 0 to 4 over the course of 1 cycle
```

summary.text: Layer values over the same time range.

content.text:
```ts
stack(0, sine(), square()) // layers a sine wave and square wave over a constant 0 value.
```

summary.text: Round to a particular step.

content.text:
```ts
random().round(0.25) // random values rounded to nearest 0.25
```

summary.text: Subtract a value or pattern.
Return the current time in cycles.

content.text:
```ts
t() // current time e.g. 3.25 (3 cycles and a quarter)
```

```ts
t(4) // current time modulo 4
```

summary.text: Toggle 1s and 0s when the condition is met.

content.text:
```ts
rarely().toggle() // toggles between 1 and 0 each time rarely() returns 1
```

summary.text: Generate a triangle wave from min to max over one cycle

content.text:
```ts
tri(0, 1) // a triangle wave from 0 to 1 over the course of 1 cycle
```

summary.text: Compare values. If one is true and the other is false, return 1, else 0.

content.text:
```ts
set(1).xor(1) // returns 0
```

summary.text: Add a value or pattern.
Compare values. If both are true, return 1, else 0.

content.text:
```ts

```

readme.text:
# Satori
A live coding language for unlimited pattern interference. It supersedes Zen, which was restricted to grid-based event triggering. Satori offers fully flexible timing, and allows parameters from any musical layer to control or transform those of any other. As with Zen, it also includes a simple API for designing, running, and sonifying quantum algorithms via its built-in simulator.

The codebase is modular by design. You can use Satori as a complete live coding environmentcombining the core language, editor, console, help docs, and synthesis engineor import individual modules into your own projects. See the docs below for different use cases. A fully functional version of Satori is hosted at: [satori.cephasteom.co.uk](https://satori.cephasteom.co.uk).

## Local Development
To run this project locally, as a complete application:
* clone this repo
* run
`nvm use`

(node version manager) to change node to correct version
*
`npm i`

to install dependencies
*
`npm run dev`

for hot file reloading
* or
`npm run build`
and
`npm run preview`

to use bundled package

## To use Satori in your own applications
Handlers are functions that process events. Each event has an ID (source), parameters, a trigger time, and a flag indicating whether it is a mutation or a regular event.
You can create custom handlers for Satori to connect to your system, or use Satoris built-in ones.

## To use standalone synth engine (Oto)
You can use the synth engine directly, without the need to write Satori code. Simply initialise Oto, then send your own events via the handler.
## To use standalone patterning language

```js
import { Pattern, methods } from './core/Pattern'

const p = new Pattern()
console.log(p.sine().query(0,1)) // query pattern between 0 and 1 cycles

const { saw } = methods // if you want to nest, get nested methods from methods object
const p2 = new Pattern()
console.log(p2.coin().fast(8).ifelse(
    saw(0,10),
    saw(10,1)
))
```
## To use the standlaone code editor

```js
import { init } from './editor'

init('#editor')

window.addEventListener("evaluateCode", (e) => console.log(e.detail.code));
```
Will load the editor in the element provided by the id. Default is
`#editor`
. Listen out for the
`evaluateCode`

event to handle the editor output.

## To use the standalone console
Initialise the console, passing in the element in which it should render. Default is
`#console`
. Send messages to the console using the BroadcastChannel interface. Types are
`info`
`success`
, and
`error`

.

## Acknowledgements
* This series of blog posts by Froos helped me finally crack time: [garten.salat.dev](https://garten.salat.dev/idlecycles/).
* Code editor built with: [Prism](https://github.com/jonpyt/prism-code-editor/?tab=readme-ov-file).
* Mini-language built on: [PegJS](https://github.com/pegjs/pegjs).
* Quantum simulator built with: [Quantum Circuit](https://www.npmjs.com/package/quantum-circuit).
